clinical_study.brief_title: Platelet Rich Plasma (PRP) Injections For Knee Osteoarthritis
clinical_study.official_title: Clinical Results Of Platelet Rich Plasma (PRP) Injections For Knee Osteoarthritis (KOA), Our Experience At Midterm Follow Up

lead_sponsor.agency: Azienda Ospedaliero-Universitaria Consorziale Policlinico di Bari

clinical_study.source: Azienda Ospedaliero-Universitaria Consorziale Policlinico di Bari

brief_summary.textblock:
It was conducted a prospective study with a series of 153 patients treated with PRP injections in patient affected by knee osteoarthritis. One independent observer performed clinical and functional evaluations at T0 (recruitment), T1 (one month after the injection), T2 (three months after the last injection) and T3 (six months after the last injection).
The Western Ontario and McMaster Universities Osteoarthritis Index (WOMAC), the Knee Score Society (KSS) score and the Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) were evaluated and recorded for each patient at each follow up.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Day 0; Month 1; Month 3; Month 6 (after the injection)
primary_outcome.description: The knee pain was quantified using the Visual Analogic Scale ranging from 0 (no pain) to 10 (worst imaginable pain).

intervention.description: The 5 mL PRP concentrate was injected every week for three times, starting from recruitment. The patient was placed supine whit a knee flexion of 90Â°.All the procedures were carried out in an aseptic condition, injected in the knee soft spot through an anterior approach, using a 21-gauge needle.

study_pop.textblock: One hundred and fiftythree patients referring to the Orthopaedic and Trauma Unit of the local University Hospital between January 2018 and January 2020 with knee osteoarthritis
